Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Limits of classical models for photosynthetic light harvesting

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traditional pictures of the initial, light harvesting, stages of photosynthesis, assume that light induced excitations hop randomly between pigment molecules. Surprisingly, recent experiments showed that excitations can exist in quantum superposition states that result in coherent population beating between pigments, instead of classical hops. Such quantum interference effects are usually ignored in biology, since biological objects are far removed from the isolated conditions typically used to produce these effects in the laboratory. My results provide a theoretical explanation of how and why the observed quantum beats in photosynthetic complexes may contribute to their biological function.

In terms of broader impact, I taught techniques and scientific best-practices, in addition to providing career advice, to the mostly undergraduate researchers in my host laboratory. My findings could also contribute towards technology with a direct societal benefit, in the form of enhanced artificial photosynthesis or bio-fuel production.

I also engaged in a number of activities which enhanced my understanding of Taiwan's culture and people. I travelled all around Taiwan from my base in Taipei in northern Taiwan, including the east coast (Hualien) and the south (Kaohsiung), when not otherwise travelling went on day trips in the Taipei area each weekend. I visited many temples, night markets, museums and local landmarks. Most of my travels and meals were with Taiwanese students, either from the group that organizes the EAPSI program in Taiwan or my host laboratory.
